t: Psalm 90
BOOK IV
Psalms 90–106
A prayer of Moses the man of God.
Lord,*pn you have been our dwelling place throughout*ld all generations.
Before*ln the mountains were born or*ld you brought forth the whole world, from*ld everlasting to everlasting you are God.
You*pn turn people back to dust, saying,*ld “Return to dust, you mortals.”
A*ln thousand years in your sight are*ld like a day that has just gone by, or*ld like a watch in the night.
Yet*ln you sweep people away in the sleep of death— they*ld are like the new grass of the morning:
In*ln the morning it springs up new, but*ld by evening it is dry and withered.
We*pn are consumed by your anger and*ld terrified by your indignation.
You*ln have set our iniquities before you, our*ld secret sins in the light of your presence.
All*ln our days pass away under your wrath; we*ld finish our years with a moan.
Our*ln days may come to seventy years, or*ld eighty, if our strength endures; yet*ln the best of them are but trouble and sorrow, for*ld they quickly pass, and we fly away.
If*ln only we knew the power of your anger! Your*ld wrath is as great as the fear that is your due.
Teach*ln us to number our days, that*ld we may gain a heart of wisdom.
Relent,*pn Lord!*s How long will it be? Have*ld compassion on your servants.
Satisfy*ln us in the morning with your unfailing love, that*ld we may sing for joy and be glad all our days.
Make*ln us glad for as many days as you have afflicted us, for*ld as many years as we have seen trouble.
May*ln your deeds be shown to your servants, your*ld splendor to their children.
May*pn the favor of the Lord our God rest on us; establish*ld the work of our hands for us— yes,*ld establish the work of our hands.
